Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Biochemical Markers in Predicting Outcomes After Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included age 18-65 years, radiological confirmation of SAH, and presentation within 96 hours of ictus.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised to receive either simvastatin or placebo.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate whether early biochemical markers can predict poor outcomes in patients with aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) at discharge and 6 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 803 patients were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Higher baseline levels of C-reactive protein (CRP), glucose, and white blood cells, and lower levels of hematocrit, albumin, and hemoglobin were associated with poor outcomes at discharge.

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events related to the intervention were reported.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the British Heart Foundation and Wellcome Trust.
